articles.title: Small Craft Advisory in Effect for Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, the British Virgin Islands, Montserrat, St. Kitts, and Nevis
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: Small Craft Advisory in Effect for Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, British Virgin Islands, Montserrat, St. Kitts, and Nevis. The advisory covers the eastern and northern sides of the islands, out to 20 nautical miles. The threat level to life, livelihood, property, and infrastructure for mariners is rising to moderate.

articles.title: Millions to swelter through new heatwave
articles.author: Rhiannon Lewin
articles.summary: Another heatwave is expected to sweep Australia through the weekend and into next week. The Bureau of Meteorology has issued warnings for severe to extreme heatwave conditions for parts of WA, Victoria, NSW, NT, SA, and Tasmania. Parts of Queensland and ACT were spared from the heatwave.

articles.title: Severe heatwave warning issued for millions of Aussies this weekend
articles.author: Rhiannon Lewin
articles.summary: Another heatwave is expected to sweep Australia through the weekend and into next week. The Bureau of Meteorology has issued warnings for severe to extreme heatwave conditions for parts of WA, Victoria, NSW, NT, SA, and Tasmania. Parts of Queensland and ACT were spared from the heatwave.

articles.title: Genealogy Today: How the St. Lucia flood changed the Netherlands
articles.author: Becky McCreary
articles.summary: The low coastlines of Northern Germany, Denmark, Great Britain and the Netherlands are susceptible to storm tides generated by the North Sea. Since 838, major storm tides have decimated farm land and killed thousands of people. The Netherlands is a flat agricultural land of which 20% to 33% sits below sea level.

articles.title: Spring Fever
articles.author: Rich Cooley Daily
articles.summary: Brandon Miller of Browntown was fishing along the South Fork of the Shenandoah River at Front Royal on a recent morning. Ice on the river has begun to melt as temperatures reached near 50 degrees and Miller had a touch of spring fever as he cast his line fishing.

articles.title: 'Unacceptable: Tracking the Increase in Antisemitic Attacks in Australia Over Time'
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: There has been a spate of anti-Semitic attacks in Australia since the Israel-Gaza war. Synagogues, homes, cars and even a childcare centre have been firebombed and defaced with vile graffiti. Alex Ryvchin, co-chief executive of the Executive Council of Australian Jewry, called out 'an evil at work in this country'

articles.title: Seed security project aims to tackle climate crisis
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: The International Rescue Committee and Unilever have teamed up to launch the "Pakistan Seed Security Prototype," an initiative aimed at building resilience within farming communities through green entrepreneurship to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Pakistan's increasing reliance on glaciers and rivers for water is exacerbating challenges for agriculture, a cornerstone of Pakistan's economy.

articles.title: Assam among 6 states vulnerable to climate variations
articles.author: Prabin Kalita
articles.summary: Economic Survey 2024-25 was tabled by Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman in Parliament on Friday. It flagged agricultural sustainability concerns in six states, including rice-predominant Assam. The survey underscores climate change as problematic due to its intensification of weather variability and increased frequency of dry spells during the monsoon season.

articles.title: Overcoming climate change requires system change
articles.author: David Suzuki
articles.summary: 2014 was the hottest year on record for land and ocean. Average global temperature breached the 1.5 C threshold for the first time last year. Every year for the past 10 years has been the hottest. We are halfway to Pliocene-level warmth in just 150 years. We have time and opportunity to create a better world from this crisis, but it's quickly running out.

articles.title: Playing in the Dirt: Gardening In A Changing Climate
articles.summary: 97.9 The Hill and Chapelboro.com partner with NC State Extension Master Gardener volunteers of Orange County for 'Playing in the Dirt' column. North Carolina is experiencing warmer temperatures, more frequent extreme rainfall and a rise in sea level due to climate change. In 2023, the U.S. Department of Agriculture released a new Plant Hardiness Zone Map that moved Orange County into Zone 8a from Zone 7b.

articles.title: Katharine Hayhoe, climatologist: ‘In the last year alone, China installed more solar panels than the US in its entire history'
articles.author: Clemente Álvarez
articles.summary: Katharine Hayhoe is a professor at Texas Tech University and chief scientist at The Nature Conservancy. She lives in conservative U.S. state of Texas. She is worried that the United States will not listen to climate scientists. She believes that people need to be more aware of the link between climate change and disasters.

articles.title: Another unwelcome consequence of climate change: an explosion of urban rats
articles.author: Karen Kaplan
articles.summary: The warmer it gets, the faster rats multiply in cities. Americans endure well over $27 billion worth of property damage each year at the hands of rats. They also suffer from diseases such as hantavirus, murine typhus and bubonic plague.

articles.title: More rats infesting cities as scientists say warmer temperatures mean more rodent babies
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEINWASHINGTON
articles.summary: Rat infestation in many world cities is soaring, especially in Washington. New study blames warming temperatures, urbanization and other human actions for the rise in rat infestations in cities that are warming the fastest. Rats have physiological challenges in the cold weather months.

articles.title: Inside the fight to save towns in path of fire disaster
articles.author: Rachael Ward
articles.summary: Australia is one of the most fire prone areas but when it happens like this, it happens. It's still sad and confronting, but it's still Australia's reality, Mr Mitchell says. It is still sad but it is still Australia. It happens.

articles.title: Ocean Warming Rate Quadruples Over Four Decades, Accelerating Climate Change
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: The rate of temperature rise has quadrupled since the 1980s, according to a study in Environmental Research Letters. The ocean surface has also risen by 4°C since the 1970s, which is a troubling acceleration in ocean warming, the study claims.

articles.title: Climate point: Fire, ice and the Doomsday Clock
articles.author: Dinah Voyles Pulver
articles.summary: The Doomsday Clock ticked closer to midnight this week. The world's largest iceberg broke away from the ocean floor and is moving northeast. A California judge ruled that environmentalists had not proven that a lithium extraction project known as Hells Kitchen was not properly studied. The Indianapolis Zoological Society announced its six finalists for the $250,000 Indianapolis Prize for animal conservation.

articles.title: Another unwelcome consequence of climate change: an explosion of urban rats
articles.author: The Los Angeles Times
articles.summary: The warmer it gets, the faster rats multiply in cities. The species is well-adapted to take food and convert it into new baby rats that scamper around your neighborhood. The warmer the climate, the more food the rats take and the faster they turn it into babies.

articles.title: 'Baking' heat to reach southern states on weekend as 'intensely heavy rainfall' hits north Queensland
articles.author: weather reporter
articles.summary: "Baking heat" from Western Australia's north is forecast to spread into south-eastern Australia this weekend. There are "severe" heatwave warnings in place across several major capitals. It includes temperatures as high as 38C and 39C for three days straight through Melbourne, Adelaide and into the 30s in Hobart. Northern Queensland residents are being told to brace for "intensely heavy rainfall" and flash flooding.

articles.title: ‘Ireland needs to be more resilient to storms' as 74,000 remain without power
articles.author: Grinne N. Aodha
articles.summary: 'Climate change is having an impact to a significant degree in our country and we have to step-change our resilience in respect of that, in other words, we will have similar storms to this in the years to come.   Â

articles.title: Rats! More rodents are infesting cities as scientists say warmer temperatures mean more rat babies
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: Rat infestation in many world cities appears to be soaring, especially in Washington. New study blames climate change, urbanization and other human actions for the increase.      .   in Washington, a new study blames the increase on climate change.

articles.title: Why climate change may be making your city's rat problem worse
articles.author: Dino Grandoni
articles.summary: Washington, D.C., San Francisco, Toronto and New York have the highest urban rat populations due in large part to rising average temperatures, according to an analysis of 16 cities published Friday. The trend is most pronounced in Washington, followed by San Francisco and San Francisco.

articles.title: Why climate change may be making your city's rat problem worse
articles.author: Dino Grandoni
articles.summary: There is an increase in urban rat populations around the world due in large part to rising average temperatures. The trend is most pronounced in Washington, D.C., followed by San Francisco, Toronto and New York. The research is the first to find a link between climate change and rat populations.

articles.title: How do climate scientists maintain their hope in a warming world?
articles.author: Bianca Hall
articles.summary: Last year was the hottest year on record. Global temperatures were on average 1.55 degrees higher than the pre-industrial period. The 10 hottest years in recorded history have been the past 10 years. Andrew King, an associate professor in climate science, has had his fair share of existential angst watching climate change accelerate.

articles.title: Record-breaking January heat set to smash records in towns across Queensland and Western Australia amid historically hot summer for the Outback
articles.author: Alison Osborne
articles.summary: It's been a very hot January in parts of Outback Australia. Many towns are on track to record their hottest January on record. Temperatures are up to 5C above the average in some regions, easily eclipsing previous records. Alice Springs has now recorded 11 days in a row over 40C. It's the longest run of 40C+ days since December 2019. February is going to be very hot as well.

articles.title: How do climate scientists maintain their hope in a warming world?
articles.author: Bianca Hall
articles.summary: At the Paris Climate Accord, countries agreed to try to limit global temperatures to 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial temperatures. Dr Martin Jucker compared the experience of climate scientists to that of doctors. Dr Simon Bradshaw believes purpose leads to hope. Dr Kimberley Reid believes the media's reporting on climate is biased towards the negative stories.

articles.title: AP Touts Study That Projects Millions Of European Heat Deaths Using Debunked Model, Shaky Stats
articles.author: Thomas Richard
articles.summary: A recent Associated Press article said that Europe could face 2.3 million annual heat-related deaths by 2100 unless drastic emission reductions are implemented. The study was based on an outmoded computer climate model RCP 8.5, which is discredited by science. Cold deaths outnumber heat deaths by a factor of 10 in Europe. Cold winters have already reduced mortality.

articles.title: Climate change threatens the mental well-being of youths. Here's how to help them cope
articles.author: Bernard J. Wolfson
articles.summary: A growing body of research shows that adolescents and young adults in the U.S. and abroad are worried about the impact of climate change on their lives today and in the future. Rammy Assaf, a pediatric emergency physician at Children's Hospital of Orange County, administered a survey on climate change to over 800 kids ages 12-17 and their caregivers.

articles.title: Climate change threatens the mental well-being of youths. Here's how to help them cope
articles.author: Bernard J. Wolfson
articles.summary: A growing body of research shows that adolescents and young adults in the U.S. and abroad are worried about the impact of climate change. Rammy Assaf, a pediatric emergency physician at Children's Hospital of Orange County, administered a survey on climate change to over 800 kids ages 12-17 and their caregivers last year.

articles.title: The warming Arctic is now a carbon source, report finds
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: The Arctic region has shifted from storing carbon dioxide to releasing it into the atmosphere, according to the 2024 Arctic Report Card released by the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The report, authored by 97, is not surprising, but it's still sobering.

articles.title: Scientists Stumped By 2024's Heat Spike, But Media Still Foment Climate Panic
articles.author: Thomas Richard
articles.summary: 2014 was the hottest year of instrumental period, but why it was so warm is not clear, even with the backdrop of increasing global temperatures. The spike in already elevated global temperatures of 2023 and 2024 is beyond what can be explained by more CO2 in the atmosphere and can't be explained with El Niño, volcanic emissions or the decline in ship fuel pollution.

articles.title: Shifting Seasons: A new series from our Local Alert Weather Meteorologists looking at the impacts of climate change in Central Oregon
articles.author: Shannon Brady
articles.summary: "Shifting Seasons" will focus on the climate challenges impacting Central Oregon and the Pacific Northwest today. KTVZ News will present both sides of the conversation. Shifting Seasons will air monthly on KTVz News.      .

articles.title: Shifting Seasons
articles.author: Shannon Brady
articles.summary: "Shifting Seasons" will focus on the climate challenges impacting Central Oregon and the Pacific Northwest today. The series will air once a month on KTVZ news. It will explore the concerns you might have about how climate change is affecting your community today and what might happen if we don't act.

articles.title: Shifting Seasons: A new series from our KTVZ News meteorologists looks at Central Oregon climate challenges
articles.author: Shannon Brady
articles.summary: Monthly series will focus on all climate impacts and issues. KTVZ News series, "Shifting Seasons" will air monthly on KTVQ News. It will explore the climate challenges impacting Central Oregon and the Pacific Northwest today, from wildfires to drought, water availability and more.

articles.title: As Europe heats up, urban death rates could soar, study warns
articles.author: Yiannis Elafros
articles.summary: Climate change could increase premature deaths in European cities by up to 50% over the coming decades. Southern Europe, including Athens, is facing the greatest impact. Researchers stress the importance of mitigating climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions and investing in sustainable city planning to counteract rising temperatures.

articles.title: Pakistan needs $348 billion by 2030 to tackle climate change, warns World Bank
articles.author: Monitoring Desk
articles.summary: Pakistan will require $348 billion in investments between 2023 and 2030 to address its climate change challenges. Pakistan is ranked as the fifth most climate-vulnerable nation globally. The World Bank committed to providing Pakistan with $20 billion over ten years under its Country Partnership Framework (CPF).

articles.title: Temperatures in the Netherlands rising twice as fast as global average
articles.author: Peter Cluskey in The Hague
articles.summary: Temperatures in the Netherlands are rising twice as fast as the global average. The country is warming by 0.4% every 10 years. Rising sea levels pose the greatest long-term risk. About a third of the Netherlands lies below sea level. The last time flooding led to serious loss of life was on February 1st, 1953.

articles.title: Misinformation and disinformation amplify international risk issues
articles.author: Ludwig Federigan
articles.summary: In the World Economic Forum's Global Risks Report 2025, misinformation and disinformation are listed as the fourth biggest risk in terms of severity. Misinformation undermines disaster preparedness efforts, sowing confusion among communities and hindering public awareness campaigns. In the Philippines, where climate change's consequences are felt severely, the stakes are even higher. Seven out of 10 adult Filipinos believe the problem of misinformation is serious.

articles.title: Responding to United States' withdrawal from Paris Agreement
articles.summary: The recent decision by President Trump to withdraw the United States from the Paris Agreement on climate change has significant implications on global climate action and international cooperation. The withdrawal undermines the spirit of international cooperation and weakens the global framework for addressing climate change. It costs RM9.73 for the 1st month, RM13.90 thereafters, RM12.33/month, and RM8.63/month.

articles.title: Warning issued to anyone with crows or jackdaws in garden
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: Birds' numbers in the UK have declined by 7% since 2018 due to habitat loss, pesticide use and climate change. Gardeners are being warned not to rake up the leaves in their gardens as birds rely on them to find food during the cold winter months.

articles.title: Letter: Trump could have learned from Oak Ridge Power Squadron courses
articles.author: Virginia M. Jones
articles.summary: Virginia M. Jones wishes Donald Trump had taken the U.S. Power Squadron courses some years ago. The organization was created to make boating safer by offering courses including seamanship, piloting, weather and navigation. Captains of boats have to work with nature because the captain cannot control the waves and the wind.

articles.title: Safeguarding Nations from Climate Change: Lessons from Sinking Islands
articles.author: Adnan Aslam
articles.summary: Rising sea levels threaten to wipe out entire communities, cultures, and even sovereign states. Island nations like Tuvalu, Kiribati, and the Maldives are in a race against time to adapt, preserve their identities, and fight for their future. Technology is becoming an essential tool in safeguarding their history and ensuring their survival. Wealthy nations and global organizations must step up to help small islands adapt.

articles.title: Climate researcher fired because he refused to fly back from the Solomon Islands because he won't use planes WINS unfair dismissal payout and vows to donate £60,000 of the payout to eco groups
articles.summary: Dr. Gianluca Grimalda was fired from his job at the Kiel Institute for the World Economy in 2023 because he refused to fly back from a work trip to reduce carbon emissions. He was doing field work in Bougainville, Papua New Guinea. He took more than a month to travel from Germany to the island. He will donate roughly £60,000 of the sum to environmental protection and climate activism groups.

articles.title: Climate researcher fired because he refused to fly back from the Solomon Islands because he won't use planes WINS unfair dismissal payout and vows to donate £60,000 of the payout to eco groups
articles.author: NATASHA ANDERSON
articles.summary: Dr. Gianluca Grimalda was fired from his job at the Kiel Institute for the World Economy in 2023 because he refused to fly back from a work trip to reduce carbon emissions. He spent 40 days travelling from Europe to Bougainville, Papua New Guinea and 72 days travelling back via a mix of cargo ships, ferries, trains and coaches. He won an unfair dismissal case in January. He plans to donate roughly £60,000 of the sum to environmental protection and climate activism groups.

articles.title: Texas poultry and dairy industries face crisis as bird flu spreads rapidly
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: The rapid spread of bird flu in Texas is severely impacting poultry and dairy farms, leading to rising egg prices and milk contamination concerns. There are also growing fears of human transmission due to the spread of the bird flu.    in Texas. In the U.S. there are also concerns about human transmission.

articles.title: 15 Largest Cities in Australia, Ranked by Population
articles.author: Kimberly Olson
articles.summary: Australia is home to some of the most dynamic cities in the Southern Hemisphere. Sydney is famous for its iconic landmarks, while Melbourne is considered Australia's cultural capital. Perth is known for its pristine beaches, Kings Park and Botanic Garden and the nearby Swan Valley wine region. Cairns is a major gateway to the Great Barrier Reef and the Daintree Rainforest. Townsville is a tropical city known for access to the reef and Magnetic Island. Logan City is one of Australia's multicultural communities.

articles.title: Rising temperatures linked to increased risk of depression, study finds
articles.author: Vladimir Hedrih
articles.summary: For every 1°C increase in average annual atmospheric temperature, the odds of having at least moderate depressive symptoms increased by 13%. These increases were 14% for adults between 19 and 40 years of age and 15% for participants who had lived in the same metropolitan area for 20 years or more. The association was particularly pronounced in urban districts.

articles.title: Green energy projects add to Sami climate woes
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Amnesty International and the Sami Council say climate change is threatening the rights and livelihood of Sami indigenous people in the Arctic. There are about 100,000 Samis, many of whom live from traditional reindeer herding. The expansion of infrastructure for renewable energy production and mineral extraction is hindering their ancestral ways of living.

articles.title: Green energy projects adding to Sami people's climate woes: Amnesty
articles.author: Naij
articles.summary: Amnesty International says climate change and efforts to curb it are both threatening the rights and livelihood of Sami indigenous people in the Arctic. "Climate change threatens the culture and existence of the Sami Indigenous people in two ways," it says.

articles.title: The Arctic Has Long Been a Carbon-Capture Giant, but That's Starting to Change
articles.author: Darren Orf
articles.summary: 34 percent of the Arctic-boreal zone (ABZ) is releasing more carbon than its storing. If wildfires were added to the mix, that percentage rose to 40 percent. Previous research has already shown that the Amazon Rainforest is releasing a concerning amount of carbon into the atmosphere and that the ocean's carbon sink is weakening.

articles.title: As erosion and floods swallow buildings, Washington's coastal communities strain to adapt
articles.summary: Connie Allen lives in North Cove, Washington, a quarter mile up the road from the beach. Her property is 10 feet above sea level. Coastal flooding fueled by climate change, dam-building, and other human activity threatens that economy. Connie and her late husband built a cobble berm on the beach to stop the erosion.

articles.title: Antarctic Ice Sheet May Be Less Vulnerable Than Previously Thought
articles.author: Yale Environment 360
articles.summary: There was a time 100,000 years ago when the Antarctic was around 3 degrees C warmer than it is today. The West Antarctic ice sheet shrunk to roughly half its current size, but the adjoining Ronne Ice Shelf, which extends out into the ocean, remained intact.

articles.title: Avoid AI and catch a bus: Guardian readers share their top climate goals for 2025
articles.author: Guardian readers
articles.summary: This year Guardian readers are setting themselves goals to reduce their carbon footprint. They are following Change by Degrees' monthly guide for making meaningful environmental change in 2025. They want to eat vegetarian, use a bicycle, reduce electricity usage, learn from First Nations elders, ride the bus more often and minimise plastics.

articles.title: Developed Nations' Climate Funding Shortfall Sparks Tensions
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: India has raised concerns over insufficient climate funding from developed countries. The Economic Survey 2024-25 highlighted that the lack of adequate financial support could lead to a reassessment of Nationally Determined Contributions for the 2031-2035 period. The Chief Economic Advisor stressed the importance of domestic resources in addressing climate challenges.

articles.title: Green energy projects adding to Sami people's climate woes: Amnesty
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Amnesty International and the Sami Council say climate change is threatening the rights and livelihood of Sami indigenous people in the Arctic. About 100,000 Samis live from traditional reindeer herding in Arctic Finland, Norway, Russia and Sweden. The expansion of infrastructure for renewable energy production and mineral extraction is hindering their ancestral ways of living.

articles.title: How to Remain a Reality-Based Human in 2025
articles.summary: The first month of 2025 has been interesting with its blazing fires, bitter cold snaps and pilot episode of 'Trump Gone Wild'. The coming year is bound to challenge anyone trying to hold fast to the norms of basic human existence. Here are some meditations to help moor you to the fact- and human-centered world.

articles.title: India Ranks 7th Among Most Vulnerable Countries to Climate Change: Economic Survey
articles.author: Sentinel Digital Desk
articles.summary: Global environmental agencies have declared 2024 the hottest year ever recorded. India is facing extreme weather, such as heatwaves, floods, and cyclones, and is grappling with severe weather in India.   Â. Â   y  y

articles.title: Climate change threatens potato, cabbage, and cucumber cultivation in Ukraine
articles.summary: Global warming is affecting agriculture in Ukraine, putting traditional crops like potatoes, cabbage, and cucumbers at risk. The success of this year's harvest will largely depend on rainfall during the growing season. The issue extends beyond Ukraine and requires agronomic innovation worldwide.

articles.title: Ocean Temperatures Are Rising Much Faster Than Scientists Expected.
articles.author: Darren Orf
articles.summary: The global mean sea surface temperature is rising 400 percent faster than it was in the late 1980s. Scientists at the University of Reading estimate that the warming witnessed within the past 40 years will be eclipsed in less than 20 years without mitigation of greenhouse emissions. In 2023-2024, the ocean hit record high temperatures for 450 days straight.

articles.title: HUMBOLDT LIFE: Meet Hygrocybe coccinea, the Scarlet Waxy Cap!
articles.summary: Hygrocybe coccinea is a member of the mushroom genus Hygrophora. It is found across the Northern Hemisphere from China and Japan to Europe and North America. The small bright red mushroom is a familiar sight in unimproved grasslands in Europe in late summer and autumn and woodlands in North America in winter.

articles.title: NC officials make urgent request to lawmakers on Helene, other storms
articles.author: Mike Stewart
articles.summary: Western North Carolina will need billions more dollars from the federal and state government to accomplish its recovery goals. The region saw historic flooding from Hurricane Helene last year, which resulted in almost $60 billion in damages. Eastern North Carolina is still struggling from previous hurricanes.

articles.title: Home Energy: Another Win-win
articles.author: Postmedia Staff
articles.summary: It's been a cold winter in Canada and energy bills have increased. 50-60% of home energy costs in Canada go directly to keeping warm in winter. Most people in Ontario still rely on fossil fuels for winter heat, with natural gas-fuelled furnaces being the most popular source of heat.

articles.title: Flooding: Sabah's drainage systems need urgent review, says Kitingan
articles.author: Sandra Sokial
articles.summary: There is an urgent need to reassess Sabah's drainage systems and waterway infrastructure to manage recurring flood issues. Heavy rainfall continues to cause extensive damage to infrastructure and displace thousands of residents. Agriculture, Fisheries and Food Industry Minister emphasized the urgent need for upgrades to the state's irrigation and drainage systems.

articles.title: 13 First Alert Weather @6am (1/31)-Record warmth in the rearview mirror as precipitation and colder weather return for February
articles.summary: Record warmth in the rearview mirror as precipitation and colder weather return for February. First Alert Weather @6am (1/31) is about the weather forecast for today, January 31st, and it's going to be cold and wet.

articles.title: Guest opinion: John Balassa: Interaction between water and climate change requires grave concern
articles.author: John Balassa
articles.summary: Climate change has a negative impact on water resources in Colorado. The St. Vrain watershed, which includes Boulder, has experienced drought conditions in 55% of the weeks since 2000. Global sea levels will rise by an average of one foot above 2000 sea levels by 2050. The Ogallala Aquifer, which supports much regional agriculture, has dropped significantly. The scarcity of groundwater compels a shift to less productive dryland farming.

articles.title: India ranks 7th among nations most vulnerable to climate change
articles.summary: Economic Survey highlights India's growing vulnerability to extreme weather events, slow onset phenomena like sea-level rise, biodiversity loss, and worsening water insecurity. It comes as global environmental agencies declared 2024 as the hottest year on record and India as the seventh most vulnerable country to climate change.

articles.title: Indonesia deforestation rises for third year running: NGO
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Deforestation in Indonesia rose in 2024 for the third year running, according to an environmental NGO. A government official disputes the NGO's figures, saying they mischaracterise deforestation in the country.      .   in Indonesia.  in

articles.title: World News  Pakistan Needs USD 350 Billion to Combat Climate Change: WB
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: The World Bank estimates Pakistan needs USD 350 billion to combat climate change between 2023 and 2030. Pakistan is currently the fifth most climate-vulnerable country in the world, according to the Global Climate Risk Index. Pakistan also faces some of the highest disaster risk levels in the World, ranking 23rd out of 194 countries.

articles.title: Pakistan's $350 Billion Climate Challenge: A Critical Call for Action
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The World Bank has called for Pakistan to mobilize $350 billion to effectively tackle climate change from 2023 to 2030. Pakistan is the fifth most climate-vulnerable country globally according to the Global Climate Risk Index. In 2022, devastating floods affected 33 million people and displaced 8 million, causing damage worth $14.9 billion.

articles.title: Impact of Global Warming on Children: Educational and Health Challenges
articles.summary: UNICEF has released a report on the impact of climate change on children's education and health. In 2024, one out of seven school-going children worldwide will experience disruptions in their education due to climate change. In 2023 alone, nearly 50 million students in India suffered from the effects of heatwaves and extreme temperatures. Global warming has disrupted Indian society, the environment, wildlife, and agriculture. The world is facing a massive challenge in controlling global warming but little action has been taken.

articles.title: India will have above-average maximum temperatures in February, weather office says
articles.author: Rajendra Jadhav
articles.summary: India is set to see above-average temperatures in February after a warmer January. The weather poses a risk to winter-sown crops such as wheat, rapeseed and chickpea. Maximum and minimum temperatures in most parts of the country would be above average in February.

articles.title: About 1.8m people in KP at risk of climate change-induced health issues: report
articles.author: Zahid Imdad
articles.summary: An estimated 1.8 million people in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa are at risk of climate change-induced health issues in the coming years, according to a research-based adaptation plan issued by the provincial health department. Vector-borne diseases like malaria and dengue are projected to rise by 30–40 per cent in KP. Waterborne illnesses such as diarrhoea could see a 20 per cent increase due to frequent flooding and declining water quality. Respiratory illnesses, including asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), are also expected to surge by 20%. Hospitals in KP are anticipated to face a 20pc increase in patient influx, placing additional pressure on

articles.title: Nature Struggling to Adapt to Milder Winters
articles.author: Deutsche Welle
articles.summary: Climate change is making winter milder, disrupting the cold weather routine of plants, birds, insects, mammals and amphibians. Some species are not bothered by this, and others can benefit from it, but for many creatures, milder winters are a real danger.

articles.title: Pakistan requires $348bn investment by 2030 to address climate change, says World Bank
articles.author: Khalid Kumbhar
articles.summary: The World Bank estimates Pakistan needs $350 billion to combat climate change between 2023 and 2030. Pakistan is currently the fifth most climate-vulnerable country in the world, according to the Global Climate Risk Index. In 2022, floods affected 33 million people across the country and displaced 8 million people. The World Bank had earlier pledged to provide $20 billion to Pakistan under a 10-year country partnership framework.

articles.title: Experts warn of looming devastation for coastal towns: 'It would destroy the community'
articles.author: Susan Elizabeth Turek
articles.summary: Rising sea levels and strong storms threaten coastal towns in the Pacific Northwest. Cranberry bogs in Washington are in peril, as coastal erosion has raised the risk that growing areas will be contaminated with too much salt. North Cove has the fastest-eroding shoreline on the West Coast. The initiative Washaway No More aims to raise awareness about shoreline erosion through community events and product sales. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration allocated $13 million to North Cove to continue its erosion mitigation.

articles.title: Viewpoint: Tourism, fisheries, real estate are at risk as Mass. coastal waters warm
articles.author: Paul Kirshen
articles.summary: There are 47 miles of shoreline in Boston alone and 101 cities and towns of the Metropolitan Area Planning Commission are at serious risk from rising sea levels, more powerful storms and more frequent flooding. The growth in Boston's population and the introduction of cannabis cultivation have added new pressures to the region's climate challenges.

articles.title: Scientists issue warning over potential hazard lurking in 'technosphere': 'It's like a ticking time bomb'
articles.author: Laurelle Stelle
articles.summary: The world is overheating due to heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide and methane. Much of the pollution comes from dirty energy sources, including oil, gas, and coal. Some of these resources get turned into items like phones, which locks potential air pollution away, but that's only temporary. The real solution is to reduce consumption and buy less stuff.

articles.title: What's the next step in repairing the Bob Sikes Fishing Pier? Escambia County lays out plan
articles.author: Gregg Pachkowski
articles.summary: Bob Sikes Fishing Pier's concrete is deteriorating and is in need of repair in Pensacola Beach on Wednesday, Jan. 29, 2025. Joe Grandison, Jack VanBenthuysen, Joseph Gaddes and Gregg Pachkowski are fishing at the pier.

articles.title: Funding freeze dilemma
articles.author: Leroy Fearon Jr
articles.summary: The Caribbean region has long relied on USAID funding to support economic growth, social programmes, and infrastructure development. The sudden freeze in USAID assistance presents a daunting challenge for local economies. The most immediate impact is the loss of funding for critical sectors, such as health care, education, and disaster resilience. The halt in aid could lead to job losses, reduced economic activity, and a decline in overall consumer spending.

articles.title: Nature struggling to adapt to milder winters – DW – 01/31/2025
articles.author: Jeannette Cwienk
articles.summary: Climate change is making winter milder, disrupting the cold weather routine of plants and animals. Some species are not bothered by this, and others can even benefit from it, but for many creatures, milder winters are a real danger. When it gets cold, bird species head south where it's warmer and more food can be found. In order to maintain warmth, resident birds need sufficient food. Insects hibernate as eggs, for example in dried plant remains, or as pupae.

articles.title: Is India prepared to deal with the fallout of increasing emissions and long-term warming in the near future?
articles.author: Neelima Vallangi
articles.summary: In 2024, the world will be 1.6 degrees Celsius warmer than pre-industrial levels. This is a symbolic marker of the world's failure to limit warming. For a vast country like India, the challenges from climate impacts are numerous and can severely impact development goals. Krishna AchutaRao, Dean and Professor at the Centre for Atmospheric Sciences, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, analysed future heatwaves over 1.5 degrees Celsius.

articles.title: Indonesia deforestation rises for third year running: NGO
articles.author: Hong Kong Standard
articles.summary: Deforestation in Indonesia rose in 2024 for the third year running, according to an environmental NGO. Indonesia has one of the highest rates of deforestation in the world, with deforestation as one of its key drivers.       "It is worrying, as it shows the increase of legal deforestation"

articles.title: The Week Unwrapped: Are our phones fuelling a Congolese militia?
articles.author: The Week Uk
articles.summary: The Week Unwrapped is a podcast for curious, open-minded people. Olly Mann and The Week delve behind the headlines and debate what really matters from the past seven days. Previous topics have included whether solar engineering could refreeze the Arctic and why funerals are going out of fashion.

articles.title: New temperature records in Kyiv — weather was similar to April
articles.author: Liza Brovko
articles.summary: Three daily air temperature records were recorded in Kyiv on January 30. The minimum air temperature did not drop below +3.0 °C. The maximum air temperature in the afternoon reached +11.6 °C, which is 3.7 °C higher than it was on this day in the same year 2002. Kyiv has not had a climatic winter for three years in a row in 2022, 2023 and 2024.

articles.title: Proposed national disaster map key in saving lives during natural calamities--solon
articles.author: Ellson Quismorio
articles.summary: Bicol Saro Party-list Rep. Brian Raymund Yamsuan proposes the creation of a national disaster map. The country experienced a record-breaking severe typhoon season. The damage to agriculture from typhoons Kristine and Leon reached P2.9 billion.

articles.title: WMO Launches Climate Services Dashboard to Support Global Climate Action and Resilience
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has launched the Climate Services Dashboard to enhance global climate service capacities and support data-driven decision-making in climate action. According to WMO's 2024 State of Climate Services Report, only 14% of WMO Members are equipped to provide advanced climate services as of 2024. 15% of Africa's NMHSs provide climate services at less than basic levels. The dashboard has proven to be a valuable tool for countries like Mozambique.

articles.title: Disagreement over Coalition Government's new emissions target
articles.summary: Federated Farmers fear the new emissions target will lead to more forests being planted on productive land. The Government has announced its new climate change commitments. It will take 2 minutes to read the first part of this article. It takes 2 minutes for the second part to read it.

articles.title: Winter waterbird census in Çanakkale records population increase
articles.summary: There was a notable increase in bird numbers in the northwestern province of Çanakkale, according to the 2025 Winter Waterbird Census (KOSKS). The KOSKS is carried out simultaneously across the Northern Hemisphere to assess bird populations and track fluctuations. The Kavak Delta recorded the highest bird concentration this year.

articles.title: Climatologist Nikolay Petkov to FACTI: Bulgaria's region is among the most affected by climate change in Europe
articles.author: Maria Atanasova
articles.summary: Climatologist Nikolay Petkov talks to FACTI about the current global warming trend. 2024 will be the hottest year in meteorological observations and is 1.6° warmer than the average for the late 19th century. US President Donald Trump is withdrawing from the Paris Agreement on climate change.

articles.title: Climate change likely to threaten taonga species on subantarctic Campbell Island
articles.author: Elizabeth Brown
articles.summary: There is an increase in the average daily temperature, decrease in the number of cold days and increase in annual rainfall since 1970 on Campbell Island. The three warmest and four wettest years on record all occurred after 2011. The study predicted the trends to continue with further temperature rise and more intense rainfall and wind. Winter rainfall is expected to be particularly heavy, with a warmer atmosphere storing more water vapour and increasing the severity and intensity of downpours.

articles.title: List of all climatic regions in Kenya with their characteristics
articles.author: Lilian Wanjala
articles.summary: Climatic regions in Kenya are influenced by various factors, including the uneven distribution of solar heat, altitude, and proximity to the sea. Kenya's varied climate offers a unique blend of weather patterns influenced by altitude and geographical location. There are 5 major climatic regions that control the Kenyan climate.

articles.title: Chandigarh: Thursday was hottest January day in over 13 years
articles.author: Rajanbir Singh
articles.summary: The maximum temperature in Chandigarh reached 25.9°C on Thursday, making it the hottest January day in the city in over 13 years. Before this, January 5, 2021 held the record with a maximum temperature of 25.8°C. There is a chance of rain on Sunday, but the mercury is likely to rise further in the coming days.

articles.title: Tasmanian cattle breeder stays the course
articles.author: McPherson Media Group
articles.summary: A young man in northern Tasmania decided to turn his Angus herd into Murray Greys in 1969. He had a very productive Angus herd at the time. He later sold it to a private company.       in the 1970s, the company turned it into Murray greys.

articles.title: Climate Change Threatens African Cocoa Output
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Climate change is having a significant impact on cocoa production in West and Central Africa. The region accounts for more than 70% of global cocoa production. In Ivory Coast, up to 50% of the current cocoa-growing areas could be lost, significantly reducing production. Ghana is expected to see a decline in suitable areas, while Nigeria and Cameroon may experience an increase in arable land for cocoa.

articles.title: Ocean temperatures are rising faster and faster
articles.author: Nachrichten
articles.summary: From April 2023 to July 2024, global average sea surface temperatures were higher than ever before. This was due to the intense occurrence of the El Niño climate phenomenon. In the ocean areas between 60 degrees north latitude and 60 degrees south latitude, surface temperatures during this period were up to 0.31 degrees Celsius higher than the maximum values previously measured in the respective seasons. According to the researchers, almost half of this increase is attributable to man-made climate change.

articles.title: Can We Still Solve Climate Change?
articles.summary: Extreme weather is getting worse. The world has broken the 1.5C limit on global warming. Countries are working hard to reduce emissions and introduce new policies to combat the problem. The UN's latest annual summit in Azerbaijan did not do much to change the narrative.

articles.title: Is India prepared to deal with the fallout of increasing emissions and ...
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: With 2024 crossing the global temperature goal and the U.S. withdrawing from the Paris Agreement, changes that were expected by 2100 are now imminent in the coming decade.    “The world is moving towards climate change that was supposed to be impossible by 2100.

articles.title: Annual bird reporting event in Latvia counts 53 species
articles.summary: Report Birds in the Garden 2025 campaign has been running in Latvia since 2017. More than 10,000 birds representing 56 bird species were counted at 278 bird-feeding sites in Latvia during the campaign from January 26 to 28, 2024. The most frequently reported species in Latvia were the great tit (1,201 birds), field sparrow, house sparrow (664 birds), greenfinch (544 birds), crow (492 birds).

articles.title: Belize aiming to become regional coconut powerhouse
articles.author: Stabroek News
articles.summary: Caribbean countries are taking a more discernable effort to maximize their food production. Guyana has always been ahead of the regional pack in terms of its focus on food security. Some countries are less mindful of the role that changing weather patterns can play in compromising agricultural production and, by extension, food security in the region.

articles.title: Lessons learnt? Jamaica aiming to ‘go big' on food security
articles.author: Stabroek News
articles.summary: Jamaica will invest $6 billion over the next six years in research to improve the varieties and yields of a number of agricultural crops. Agriculture Minister Floyd Green says experience has taught the Caribbean Community the value of food security. The government will enter into the undertaking with the country's private sector.

articles.title: Northeast Wisconsinites enjoy record high January warmth
articles.author: Paul Steeno
articles.summary: It was 53 degrees in Green Bay on Thursday. It was the third warmest day on record for Green Bay in January. The previous record was 42 degrees set in 1989. People took advantage of the warm weather to do outdoor activities normally reserved for the springtime.

articles.title: First Alert Weather @ Ten: Record warmth in the rearview mirror as precipitation and colder weather return for February (1/30/25)
articles.summary: Record warmth in the rearview mirror as precipitation and colder weather return for February (1/30/25). First Alert Weather @ Ten is on at 10:00 p.m. ET.   .     Â   in

articles.title: Adapting to the climate crisis will require societal transformation, not least in China and Hong Kong
articles.author: John Barkdull
articles.summary: 2014 was the warmest year on record in the world. Last year was warmest in China and Hong Kong. Global CO 2 emissions are still increasing. China is the source of one-third of those emissions. The current focus on GDP growth needs to be replaced with measures that prioritise social well-being and environmental health.

articles.title: Thousands of cranes overwinter in central Nebraska: 'Past few years have been kind of crazy'
articles.author: Marjie Ducey
articles.summary: For the second straight year, thousands of sandhill cranes have stayed in central Nebraska for the winter. About 10,000 to 15,000 have overwintered on a stretch of the Platte River from Wood River to Grand Island. Last year, a polar vortex drove the birds south in January, but that hasn't happened this year. With little snow, the birds have been able to feed in cornfields on existing waste grain that was dropped or missed during harvest season.

articles.title: Eyewitness News at 11pm - January 30, 2025
articles.summary: NC Hurricane survivors may not get homes rebuilt without more funding for hurricane relief.      Â   for more funding  for Hurricane relief. For more information, go to: http://www.cnn.com/news/helping-hurricane-victims-rebuild-homes.

articles.title: Africa: Can We Still Solve Climate Change?
articles.author: Felix Dodds
articles.summary: The Earth's average temperature has exceeded 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels for the first time. Extreme weather is getting more frequent and severe. The world has been doing a lot to reduce emissions. Brazil's André Corrêa do Lago has been chosen as president of COP30.

articles.title: Implications of US exit from WHO, Paris Accords
articles.author: Punch
articles.summary: The entire world is alarmed by the decision of Donald Trump to withdraw from WHO and the Paris Accords on climate change. These actions are contained in an executive order. Click here to read the full news article.   Â     .

articles.title: Australia's road toll is breaking records, what's happening?
articles.author: Ben Silvester
articles.summary: Australia's road toll has risen for four straight years for the first time since 1966. Safety experts are calling for action to reduce the toll.      Â  .   in Australia's roads are dangerous for people's safety, according to experts.

articles.title: Climate mitigation: Challenges facing African countries
articles.author: Chikodi Okereocha
articles.summary: Nigeria and other African countries contribute four per cent of global greenhouse gas emissions. They are disproportionately vulnerable to climate crises, losing an average of five per cent to climate devastation. Of the $277 billion required annually until 2030, Africa receives only $30 billion a year. Experts are pushing for prioritisation of innovative financial structures and instruments.

articles.title: Wildfire Smoke Spreads Toxins, Grimes Urban Areas: Study
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: There has been an increase in the number of wildfires in Western Canada due to climate change. Wildfire smoke can carry toxins hundreds of kilometres away. The team is following up by analyzing samples from multiple cities in Canada and the U.S. collected during the 2022 wildfire season.

articles.title: Indigenous rock art threatened as bushfires rage on
articles.author: William Ton
articles.summary: Fire crews are fighting blazes in Victoria's richest concentration of Indigenous rock art. The blazes are out-of-control, ahead of an expected heatwave and the expected arrival of the summer heatwave.    i.e. a hot, dry and windy weather.

articles.title: Bushfire Alert: Standley Chasm, West MacDonnell Ranges
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: There is a heightened level of threat due to the Bushfire. The fire is spreading on one or more fronts and effective containment strategies are not in place for the entire perimeter. Drivers in the area are urged to slow down, turn on headlights and drive safely for the safety of firefighting crews.

articles.title: The ocean is warming 400% faster than it was four decades ago
articles.summary: Rising ocean temperatures have become a major concern for scientists and environmentalists. El Niño, the 2022 Hunga Tonga volcanic eruption and new shipping regulations introduced in 2020 are contributing factors to the rise in ocean temperatures. The sun is currently at the peak of its solar maximum, giving off more solar energy that is trapped within the atmosphere.

articles.title: Red Cross Volunteers clean Lowman's Bay
articles.author: Webmaster Nbsp
articles.summary: Some 50 volunteers from the St Vincent and the Grenadines Red Cross Society and St. Vincent Grammar School's Environmental Club cleaned the beach at Lowman's Bay on Saturday, January 25, 2025. The objective of the activity was to respond to one environmental challenge in the area and improve the aesthetics of the community beach.

articles.title: VIDEO: Fire crews work to prevent two large fires from merging in Victoria's west
articles.summary: Paul Carrigg, the CFA State Agency Commander says there is a chance the two large fires burning across Victoria's west could merge. He is giving an update on the situation as he gives an update to CFA's State Agency commander on the fires.

articles.title: JEMS using integrated community approach in climate awareness project
articles.author: Webmaster Nbsp
articles.summary: The Jems Progressive Community Organisation is using an integrated community approach to tackling climate change issues and developing a new vulnerability Risk Map of St Vincent and the Grenadines. The organisation has already worked with the communities of Chauteaubelair, the entire Vermont Valley, Spring Village, Cumberland, Mesopotamia, Park Hill and South Rivers as they are experiencing extreme climate conditions. They are promoting sustainable living through educating Vincentians on how to implement organic farming, harvesting water, recycling, coral reef restoration and beach clean-ups.

articles.title: KI experiences heatwave in lead up to first-ever Extreme Heat Awareness Day
articles.author: Hui Jin
articles.summary: Extreme Heat Awareness Day is on February 5, 2025. It's led by the Australian Red Cross and Sweltering Cities. It encourages people to get involved by educating others about extreme heat and educate others about the dangers of heat.

articles.title: $11 Million NHMRC Grants to Combat Climate Change Impacts on Health
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: Associate Professor Brad Farrant, from the University of Western Australia, has been awarded an NHMRC grant to expand 'Caring for Country' programs for Aboriginal communities. Deakin University researcher Associate Professor Luana Main will focus on reducing heat stress among workers.

articles.title: Greenhouse gas emissions grow in latest data, throwing Minnesota off target for climate goals
articles.author: The Daily Item
articles.summary: After the end of the pandemic, there was a rise in pollution from cars, trucks and other transportation. Minnesota is off track to meet its goals for reducing greenhouse gas emissions responsible for climate change, according to the report. The report was released by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

articles.title: STATEMENT: Africa Climate Director: Trump Administration's Abandonment Of The Paris Agreement Sets Dangerous Precedent
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: By abandoning the Paris Agreement, the U.S. will become the world's largest carbon emitter, according to the UNFCCC's report. The United States is historically the largest emitter of carbon in the world, and it's high in CO2 emissions.

articles.title: ‘Perfect rat storm': urban rodent numbers soar as the climate heats, study finds
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: Washington DC, San Francisco, Toronto, New York City and Amsterdam had the greatest increase in rat numbers. Eleven of the 16 cities showed'significant increasing trends' in the rat numbers, according to the study. The study looked at data from 16 cities globally.

articles.title: Cold waves in the rainforest: What they mean for wild animals
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Cold waves can cause temperatures to drop drastically in the Amazon rainforest. Researchers have investigated how animals react to this and have found out that cold waves can affect their behaviour.    i.e. they can cause extreme temperature drop in the rainforest and affect animals.

articles.title: Researcher on energy revolution: Sustainability is still a work in process
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: The world is experiencing more frequent and intense heat waves, floods, hurricanes, and wildfires due to rising greenhouse gas, according to the UN.   Â. Â   y.  y.,  y,  y, y, y.

articles.title: Rising temperatures linked to increased risk of depression, study finds
articles.author: Psy Post
articles.summary: For every 1°C increase in average annual atmospheric temperature due to climate change, the odds of having at least moderate depressive symptoms increased by 13%. The increases were 14% for adults between 19 and 40 years of age, according to new research from South Korea.

articles.title: Pakistan requires $348bn investment by 2030 to address climate change, says World Bank
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: The World Bank said Pakistan needs $350 billion to combat climate change between 2023 and 2030. Pakistan is currently the fifth most climate-vulnerable country in the world, according to the Global Climate Risk Index. Pakistan also needs $348 billion for a comprehensive response to Pakistan's climate and development challenges.

articles.title: A Weather Event With Fire Embedded
articles.author: Who What Why
articles.summary: As the embers go cold and the smoke clears, Los Angeles assesses the devastation from one of its most catastrophic urban fires. A new World Weather Attribution study found that human-caused extreme weather event with fire embedded in it played a significant role in this deadly event.

articles.title: Viewpoint: Tourism, fisheries, real estate are at risk as Mass. coastal waters warm
articles.author: Business Journal
articles.summary: The latest climate change report to raise alarms in Boston puts a spotlight on one of the most valuable economic, environmental and quality-of-life assets: the marine.   .   "Climate change report" to raise alarm in Boston raises alarms.

articles.title: Most Of Britain's Peat Bogs Could Stop Forming New Peat As The Climate Changes New Study
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: By the 2080s, most of Britain's peatlands could be too dry to form new peat, according to a new academic study by my colleagues and their colleagues.  .   ...   by the 2070s, climate change will mean most of the peatland will be dry.

articles.title: Community demands more shark mitigation funding after fatal SA attacks
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Danny Lee is asking the government to increase funding to protect ocean users in Streaky Bay. He is frustrated the community has been left to mitigate the risk of shark attacks on their coastline.      .   for more information visit: http://www.justgiving.com/councilfunding/increase-funding-to-protect-ocean-users/

articles.title: Guest opinion: John�Balassa: Interaction between water and climate change requires grave concern
articles.author: John Balassa
articles.summary: A large part of climate change is the water crisis. We feel its impacts through worsening floods, rising sea levels, shrinking ice fields, droughts, desertification, shrinking arable land, forced migration of large numbers of people and uncontrolled fires. An appalling example is the extensive

articles.title: India 7th most vulnerable country to climate change: Economic Survey
articles.author: India Today
articles.summary: India is the most vulnerable country to climate change according to the Economic Survey. It's also the most affected by global warming. It is also most vulnerable to sea-level rise, according to UNFCCC's report. It says India is most vulnerable because of population growth.

articles.title: Game over: Review of Madeleine Orr's Warming Up — How Climate Change is Changing Sport
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: is a new book. It urges sports industry to take global warming seriously. It is published by Simon & Schuster at £12.99.    for non-commercial use only. For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here.

articles.title: The ocean is warming 400% faster than it was four decades ago
articles.author: BGR
articles.summary: A new study has revealed that the surface of our oceans is warming faster than expected. Climate change has long been linked to warmer seas, but new research suggests it's escalating faster than previously thought. The study was published in the journal "The International Journal of Climatology".

articles.title: Trump's Paris Agreement exit could push Indonesia towards China for climate funding
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: The US exit from the climate accord raises concerns about Indonesia's ability to achieve its net-zero emissions goals, as the US exit raises concerns over Indonesia's future in the climate agreement.    i.e. Indonesia's net- zero emissions goals.

articles.title: Supercharged hurricanes will cause more blackouts across the US
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Some US states may see the number of power cuts caused by hurricanes jump by 60 per cent by 2100 in a high-emissions scenario. It will affect tens of millions each decade, according to some estimates.   Â   in high emissions scenario.

articles.title: Climate researcher fired because he refused to fly back from the Solomon Islands because he ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Dr. Gianluca Grimalda was fired from his job at the Kiel Institute for the World Economy in 2023 because he refused to fly back from a work trip in a bid to reduce carbon emissions. He has now won an unfair dismissal payout.

articles.title: Burundi is losing its trees: How to break heavy charcoal use and tree clearing through ...
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: is the country's biggest environmental problem. Burundi faces serious climate and environmental challenges.    i   in this context, the biggest of them is the climate change.  In this context the biggest one is the environment. In this case, it's the climate.

articles.title: Rats! Climate change is helping increase their populations in cities
articles.author: National Public Radio
articles.summary: Winters are getting warmer and shorter as the climate changes. That's helping rat populations grow in several U.S. cities, especially in the Midwest and Northeast..       in the photo is from AP/Richard Drew.

articles.title: Why climate change may be making your city's rat problem worse
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: A new study is the first to link rising temperatures and rat populations in cities around the world to rising global temperatures and rising rat populations. The study was published in the journal "Environmental Research Letters". It is based on data from the European Union and the U.S.

articles.title: Rats are thriving in Toronto. Climate change is making it worse, study suggests
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: There are more rats in Canada's largest city due to climate change, according to a new study from a group of global rodent and public health scientists. The study was published in the journal "Public Health International".       i.e.

articles.title: About 1.8m people in KP at risk of climate change-induced health issues: report
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: An estimated 1.8 million people in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa are at risk of climate change-induced health issues in the coming years, according to a research-based adaptation plan issued by the provincial health department. People in the province may face life-threatening challenges, including diseases.

articles.title: Ebre Delta birds decline as wetlands face rising threats, study finds
articles.author: Catalan News
articles.summary: A study conducted by Birdlife has found a "significant decrease" in the winter presence of migratory birds in the Ebre Delta. According to the report's authors, the decline can be attributed to "multiple pressure factors" such as changes in Ebre River and climate change.

articles.title: Climate change adversely affecting livestock sector
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: The climate change has a negative effect on livestock all over Pakistan. An integrated strategy is needed to combat the negative effects of the changing climate in Dera Ismail Khan, the southern district of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, especially in terms of livestock.

articles.title: Green energy projects adding to Sami people's climate woes: Amnesty
articles.author: Iosco County News Herald
articles.summary: Amnesty International says climate change and efforts to curb it are threatening the rights and livelihoods of Sami indigenous people in the Arctic, especially the Sami people in Sami territory. It is also threatening their rights to live off fossil fuels.

articles.title: Heathrow's third runway, Rachel Reeves and the pursuit of growth
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Readers respond to the chancellor's intentions, voicing their concerns about the climate and driving 'growth' in the medium term.   .   i   for confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 1-800-273-8255.

articles.title: Lifeline Scots food bank faces 'significant delay' to community hall move due to storm-damaged roof
articles.author: Daily Record
articles.summary: Hurricane-force gales blew the roof off Greenhills Community Hall during Storm Eowyn last Friday. Loaves and Fishes' move to the facility could be delayed by months, as a result of the damage caused by the storm.

articles.title: January 2025 was 3rd warmest in India's recorded history
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: January 2025 was the third warmest January in India since record keeping commenced in country in 1901. MeT department data shows all-India mean temperature in Jan was 18.98°C - 0.94°C higher than the normal. IMD predicted that most parts of the country would be warmer and drier than normal in Feb.

articles.title: As erosion and floods swallow buildings, Washington's coastal communities strain to adapt
articles.author: Claire Carlson
articles.summary: The ancestral homelands of the present-day Shoalwater Bay Indian Tribe date back over 2,000 years. In the late 19th and early 20th century, the Columbia River was dammed and jetties were built along its mouth and farther north at Grays Harbor. The changes affected flows of river sediment, reducing the amount of driftwood and sand that washed up on some of southwest Washington's beaches. Long Beach, a small town at the southern end of a 20-mile stretch of coastline separating the Pacific Ocean from Willapa Bay, has seen the accretion on the beach growing over 15 feet per year since 1889. Rural communities have less access to grant funding

articles.title: Joburg residents complain of increase in flies
articles.author: e NCA
articles.summary: There is a fly infestation in Johannesburg. The warmer weather is providing a breeding ground for them to breed more quickly. Entomologist Genevieve Theron says there will always be more flies in the summer this season.

articles.title: Arctic sea ice is returning to normal
articles.summary: Jed Dukett wrote a guest commentary on the bias in climate change science. Richard Brandt claims it's 'nonsense' to compare the climatic effect of sulfur pollution from volcanoes with human pollution. Arctic sea ice has been flat for the last 18 years, while CO2 has kept rising.

articles.title: Drought status unchanged throughout S.C.; fire risk remains a concern
articles.author: SCDNR
articles.summary: The drought status remains unchanged across South Carolina despite wintry weather. The S.C. Drought Response Committee decided to maintain incipient drought for 32 counties. Normal drought conditions were maintained for 14 counties from the Midlands to the southeast corner of the state. The number of fires in January was twice the five-year average, and the number of acres burned was 41% higher than usual.

articles.title: Driving Namibia's Just Transition through open innovation in the Water-Energy Nexus
articles.author: Namibian Sun
articles.summary: Namibia faces severe water shortages due to droughts, rapid urban growth, and climate change. Water scarcity and energy inefficiency are no longer distaing. Free access to articles from 12:00 is available now.   If you are an active subscriber, you can log out and back in.
